basic.title: Verification Priority
basic.description: You have limited time for issue verification. How do you prioritize tickets?

options.text: Start with highest priority and severity issues, ensuring critical fixes are verified first
options.outcome: Perfect! This ensures most important issues are verified.

options.text: Verify tickets in chronological order to address the most current issues first
options.outcome: Priority and severity should guide verification order.

options.text: Start with easiest tickets to gain the most coverage of open tickets
options.outcome: Critical issues need verification first.

options.text: Verify issues based on your familiarity with specific tickets
options.outcome: Structured prioritisation is required to address the most critical issues first.

basic.title: Environment Matching
basic.description: You need to verify a device-specific issue. What's the correct approach?

options.text: Verify on the original environment where possible, or clearly document any environment differences
options.outcome: Excellent! This maintains testing consistency.

options.text: Test on any available device to verify the issue has been resolved
options.outcome: The original environment should be prioritised as this is where the issue was raised and has been addressed.

options.text: Verify on an older device before moving onto the specified device
options.outcome: Device-specific issues require verification as users will operate many different devices.

options.text: This can be marked as verified without testing as long as functionality on the primary environment behaves as intended
options.outcome: Verification is required on specific devices the issue was raised on.

basic.title: Verification Comments
basic.description: How should you document your verification findings?

options.text: Use template format with status, date, observations, version, environments, and evidence
options.outcome: Perfect! This provides comprehensive verification documentation.

options.text: Update the ticket status, as this ensures proper traceability of the issue
options.outcome: More details are required for traceability.

options.text: Update the ticket by stating "fixed" or "not fixed" as further details are not required
options.outcome: More detailed documentation is required for developer and stakeholder information.

options.text: Add screenshots as visual representation of issues is vital for developers to debug issues
options.outcome: Written documentation is also required to accompany evidence.

basic.title: Evidence Capture
basic.description: What's the best practice for capturing verification evidence?

options.text: Use appropriate tools, highlight issues clearly, repeat demonstrations in videos
options.outcome: Excellent! This provides clear verification evidence.

options.text: Included screenshots don't need labelling as attachment should provide enough detail
options.outcome: Any submitted evidence requires clear highlighting.

options.text: Evidence capture is generally not needed as steps and description should provide enough detail
options.outcome: Visual evidence is essential for verification.

options.text: A video capture in low resolution should be sufficient evidence
options.outcome: While a video capture is good evidence, the resolution should be up to a legible standard.

basic.title: Status Updates
basic.description: An issue is partially fixed. How do you update its status?

options.text: Mark as partially fixed with a detailed explanation of the remaining issues
options.outcome: Perfect! This accurately reflects partial fixes.

options.text: Change the status to fixed, adding a note to re-open once fully fixed
options.outcome: Partial fixes should not be closed unless instructed by the client.

options.text: Update the status to not fixed without adding a comment, as the status itself indicates the ticket requires a revisit
options.outcome: Partial fix tickets require a partial fix status with full details included.

options.text: Keep the status unchanged, as the open ticket reflects the current situation
options.outcome: This type of ticket requires the correct status update with the relevant verification details.

basic.title: Issue Status
basic.description: What term describes an issue that shows some improvements but still has unresolved aspects?

options.text: Partially Fixed
options.outcome: Correct! This is an issue that has been noted as partly showing expected behaviour or improvements, but part of the issue remains unresolved.

options.text: Won't Fix
options.outcome: Won't Fix means the client has decided not to address the issue.

options.text: Not Reproducible
options.outcome: Not Reproducible means the issue cannot be recreated during testing.

options.text: Out of Scope
options.outcome: Out of Scope indicates the issue is beyond the project requirements.

basic.title: Issue Verification & Additional Testing
basic.description: What is a crucial component of issue verification that should be performed alongside retesting specific issues?

options.text: Creating detailed test cases for future test cycles
options.outcome: Creating test cases is part of planning activities and not generally part of issue verification

options.text: Interviewing developers about their implementation methods
options.outcome: Whilst comments can be added to tickets about findings and queries. Interviewing developers is not part of issue verification.

options.text: Regression testing in areas where fixes have been made
options.outcome: Correct! It is critical you ensure time for regression testing to identify new issues that may have been introduced as a result of fixes.

options.text: Redesigning the user interface to prevent future issues
options.outcome: User Interface redesign is not part of the tester's responsibility during issue verification

basic.title: Issue Verification Characteristics
basic.description: What is a key characteristic of issue verification compared to exploratory testing?

options.text: Issue verification requires less attention to detail than exploratory testing
options.outcome: Issue verification requires being Observant, Detail oriented and aware of change, so it doesn't require less attention to detail.

options.text: Issue verification is always performed by a different tester than the original test execution
options.outcome: The same tester that performed the original test execution on the system can perform the regression tests as well as different testers.

options.text: Issue verification focuses more on reporting than on detailing destructive test methods
options.outcome: Correct! The reporting process differs from, exploratory testing which is focused on detailing destructive/edge case methods and reporting the issues found. Instead, it is centred around verifying and building a picture of product quality.

options.text: Issue verification allows for more creative test approaches than exploratory testing
options.outcome: Issue verification generally relies on following a set of steps for each ticket raised rather than a more creative approach that exploratory testing employs.

basic.title: Issue Verification Terms
basic.description: What does the term "Global" mean in the context of issue verification?

options.text: The issue is present on all environments and all operating systems based on tested samples
options.outcome: Correct! Stating global is making a calculated assumption based on observations that the issue is present on all environments and all operating systems.

options.text: The issue affects all users in all countries worldwide
options.outcome: While this might seem logical, global is defined in terms of environments and operating systems, not geographic regions.

options.text: The issue requires approval from global management.
options.outcome: This is incorrect, and management should not be involved in ticket raising criteria.

options.text: The issue can only be verified by international teams.
options.outcome: This is incorrect as global issues should require the testers experience and knowledge

basic.title: Unresolved Issues
basic.description: What should a tester do if they discover that clients have not addressed issues in time for the issue verification session?

options.text: Identify unresolved issues as lower priority for retesting
options.outcome: Correct! Where possible, confirm with the project manager which & how many issues the client has been able to work on ahead of the issue verification session. If there are known unresolved issues, identify them as lower priority for retest.

options.text: Cancel the session and reschedule for a later date
options.outcome: This should not be the process. Any unresolved issues should be identified as low priority for re-test.

options.text: Test only the fixed issues and ignore all others
options.outcome: Prioritising of all issues should be the process, rather than ignoring any tickets that have any other status.

options.text: Automatically mark all untested issues as 'Not Fixed'
options.outcome: Automatically marking issues as Not Fixed without testing would be inaccurate and contradicts the purpose of verification.

intermediate.title: Regression Testing
intermediate.description: After verifying fixes, how do you approach regression testing?

options.text: Focus on areas where fixes were implemented, while also checking surrounding functionality
options.outcome: Perfect! This ensures thorough regression coverage.

options.text: Check all of the fixed issues as confirmed by the client
options.outcome: Regression testing should cover areas that have been recently modified. This may include new features or bug fixes.

options.text: Stick to minimal regression testing as previous issues have been fixed and tested during the current release
options.outcome: Regression testing reduces the risk of introducing new bugs into the system, which can be costly and time-consuming to fix later.

options.text: Focus regression testing on tester preference using experience gained during initial testing
options.outcome: Regression tests should focus on high risk areas, recent changes and core functionality.

intermediate.title: Time Management
intermediate.description: How do you manage time during a verification session?

options.text: Set goals for ticket verification numbers and allocate specific time for regression
options.outcome: Excellent! This ensures balanced coverage.

options.text: Work through verification of all tickets to completion
options.outcome: Time needs to be allocated for both issue verification and regression testing on a priority basis.

options.text: Focus time management on regression testing
options.outcome: Issue verification requires time allocation for both ticket verification and regression testing.

options.text: Focus time management and planning on issue verification
options.outcome: Issue verification requires time allocation for both ticket verification and regression testing.

intermediate.title: New Issues Discovery
intermediate.description: You find new issues during verification. How do you handle them?

options.text: Raise new tickets and note if they're related to recent fixes
options.outcome: Perfect! This tracks new issues properly.

options.text: Add any new issues to existing tickets within the project
options.outcome: Any new issues found require separate tickets.

options.text: Leave new issues for a further round of testing as issue verification should focus on current tickets
options.outcome: All issues require documentation as and when they are found.

options.text: Raise any new issue found during issue verification in the report summary
options.outcome: While new issue can be stated in a report summary, they also require tickets to be raised.

intermediate.title: Device Availability
intermediate.description: An original test device isn't available. How do you proceed?

options.text: Contact the device owner early, check device lists and consider BrowserStack with PM approval
options.outcome: Excellent! This shows correct device management.

options.text: Test on any available device to verify the issue has been resolved
options.outcome: The original environment should be prioritised, even if this is tested on BrowserStack as this is where the issue was raised and has been addressed.

options.text: Test on a similar device and document test outcome
options.outcome: Using a different device for verification should be confirmed by the project manager and all environment differences require documentation.

options.text: Mark the ticket as cannot test due to lack of device resources
options.outcome: Alternative testing options must be explored including a similar device and BrowserStack.

intermediate.title: Client Communication
intermediate.description: The client hasn't updated ticket statuses. How do you proceed?

options.text: Contact the Project Manager to confirm which issues have been worked on and prioritise known fixed issues
options.outcome: Perfect! This ensures efficient verification.

options.text: Test all tickets that have previously been raised within the project
options.outcome: Prioritisation is required as some tickets may not have been worked on by the client.

options.text: Continue with issue verification whilst awaiting updates to tickets from the client
options.outcome: Proactive communication with the Project Manager and client is required in this instance as they may not intend to work on specific tickets.

options.text: Leave the tickets that don't have any status update and include the information in the summary report.
options.outcome: It is best practice to confirm with the client which that has tickets are intended for verification.

advanced.title: Complex Issue Verification
advanced.description: A complex issue involves multiple interconnected features. How do you verify it?

options.text: Test all connected features, document dependencies, verify full workflow
options.outcome: Perfect! This ensures thorough verification.

options.text: Test the main feature and document the outcome
options.outcome: All connected features require verification and regression testing.

options.text: Test the features that are connected to the main feature as this ensures all issues have been addressed
options.outcome: Complex issues need thorough testing and all affected features require attention.

options.text: Test the specific issues that have been addressed by the client without the full feature workflow
options.outcome: All issues require verification as well as the full workflow of interconnected features.

advanced.title: Multiple Environment Issues
advanced.description: An issue affects multiple environments differently. How do you verify it?

options.text: Test each environment, document specific behaviours, note any variations
options.outcome: Excellent! This provides complete environment coverage.

options.text: Test any of the affected environments to verify the issue has been addressed by the client
options.outcome: All affected environments require testing as behaviour has been stated as environment specific.

options.text: Test the majority of environments, ascertain an average outcome and document results
options.outcome: All stated environment variations are required for verification.

options.text: Test all stated environments and document the outcome of the primary device
options.outcome: Environment differences require full documentation for traceability.

advanced.title: Regression Impact Analysis
advanced.description: Multiple fixes have been implemented. How do you assess regression impact?

options.text: Research fix relationships, test impacted areas, document any cascading effects
options.outcome: Perfect! This ensures comprehensive regression analysis.

options.text: Verify any client stated fixes specifically
options.outcome: Potential related impacts from specific bug fixes also require assessment.

options.text: Use a basic regression process to ascertain focus feature fixes
options.outcome: Thorough impact analysis is required for regression testing to explore any other areas that might be affected by a specific bug fix.

options.text: Impact analysis can be left until all specific fixes have been verified
options.outcome: Fix impacts require assessment systematically throughout verification as blocking issues could be direct impact of a current fix.

advanced.title: Verification Report Creation
advanced.description: How do you create a comprehensive verification report?

options.text: Document verified issues, regression findings, new issues, and quality assessment
options.outcome: Excellent! This provides complete verification coverage.

options.text: List all issues fixed by the client within the application release
options.outcome: All aspects need reporting not just fixed issues.

options.text: Document a basic status update of each existing issue within the release
options.outcome: Comprehensive reporting needed is required including new issues and regression details.

options.text: Document all details surrounding regression testing of the new release
options.outcome: Verification needs full documentation not just regression test reporting.

advanced.title: Quality Assessment
advanced.description: How do you assess if additional testing is needed after verification?

options.text: Analyse fix impact, regression findings, and new issues to recommend next steps
options.outcome: Perfect! This provides informed testing recommendations.

options.text: Check that all open issues within the release have been fixed
options.outcome: Other factors also need to be taken into consideration like regression findings and new issues raised.

options.text: Rely on client feedback so they can make a decision on additional testing
options.outcome: Proactive assessment required and additional testing can be judged on regression findings and new issues raised.

options.text: Await feedback from the project manager on issue verification findings to decide on additional testing
options.outcome: Quality assessment is crucial and initiative should be taken on additional testing as well as informing the project manager of the outcome.
